Various kinds of IDE¶

Vim as IDE¶

  • Code completion in Vim

  • Code highlighting

  • python linting

  • Most important things while building vim from scratch

    • For ubuntu use Vim available on Git.

    • Use the following command to do the same:

      ./configure --with-features=huge --enable-python3interp --prefix=$HOME/opt/vim`

    • Build Vim with Python3 or Python2 but not both.

    • For python code completion use vim-jedi and not others like, YouCompleteMe.

    • Install the plugin vim-conda to use python code completion in jedi.

  • Setting up Vim for Mac

    • Use only MacVim not normal Vim. Clone from MacVim repository.
    • As of now try to compile Mac with either Python 3 or Python 2, not both.
    • I configured vim to use p3.5 (python 3.5) anaconda environment.
    • Exact instructions for building Macvim is given here
    • Set environment variable CC='clang' in .bashrc
    • Set export VIMRUNTIME="/Users/nikhilpattisapu/Tools/macvim/runtime/" in .bashrc

    • You can open multiple files in vim at once bu using vim * - All files in current directory

      • :tab all will open all the files in Vim’s argument list in individual tabs

      • To close a tab, close the file in it using :q or :wq if you need to save changes first.

      • To close all tabs :qa or :wqa to save work in all tabs and quit.

      • Set shortcut in .vimrc file to navigate between tabs:

        map <C-t><up> :tabr<cr>
map <C-t><down> :tabl<cr>
map <C-t><left> :tabp<cr>
map <C-t><right> :tabn<cr>

    • All the relevant configurations are explained here. Code Folding Using SimpylFold: zo (to open a fold), zc (to close a fold), zR (to open all folds), zM (to close all folds)

    • You can comment out a block of code in python using vim in the following way.

      • Esc to leave editing mode
      • ctrl + v to go to visual mode.
      • Select the lines that you want to comment (using up/down keys)
      • Shift + I which will put editor in insert mode.
      • Insert the text that you want (in this case #)
      • press Esc

    • You can also uncomment out a a block of code

      • Ctrl + v to go to visual mode
      • Put the cursor on the first # and go down until the last comment line and press x
      • This will delete all # vertically.

    • You can indent as well as unindent your python code using the following

      • When indenting or unindenting, lines are shifted one shiftwidth to the right or left.
      • In normal mode press 5>> to shift 5 lines to right and 5<< to shift 5 lines to left.
      • Shift + v to goto visual mode which operates at line levels
      • Select the lines using cursor and use > to shift right or < to shift left.

Atom¶

  • To install a package in Atom use apm install packageName

  • To install behind proxy

    • apm config set https-proxy http://proxy.iiit.ac.in:8080 (The URL should start from http not https)
    • apm config set http-proxy http://proxy.iiit.ac.in:8080
    • apm config set proxy http://proxy.iiit.ac.in:8080

  • To modify the settings of a particular package Atom -> Preferences -> Packages -> Specific Package -> Settings

  • To enter the command-line mode

    • On Mac: Shift + Command + P
    • On Ubuntu:

  • To define a python cell use the comment in the following way # %%

  • I had some problems with the default markdown-preview package.

    • I fixed it by going to preferences -> settings -> packages -> markdown-preview -> disable then enable again.
    • Somehow, there were also some bugs w.r.t the window panes. You can modify the options in a similar way as mentioned above.

  • I faced an issue with atom where, the python code for calling a StanfordCoreNLP server was working in terminal and not working in atom. The following is the code snippet

    from pycorenlp import StanfordCoreNLP
nlp = StanfordCoreNLP('http://10.4.17.63:9000') # The server http://10.4.17.63:9000 is accessible through browser.
text = ('He went to a dentist.')
op = nlp.annotate(text, properties={'annotators': 'tokenize,ssplit,pos,depparse,parse','outputFormat': 'json'})

    My guess is that, this is due to proxy issues. I could not confirm it though.

Micro - terminal based editor¶

  • Help available here
  • Installation on Mac - brew install micro
  • Installation on ubuntu - The instructions given in the here were NOT helpful for me. So, I used the following procedure
    • Download the required package from https://github.com/zyedidia/micro/releases
    • tar -xvf micro-1.2.1-60-linux64.tar.gz
    • copy the binary micro file inside the micro-1.x.x directory to /bin/
    • Execute micro command from terminal in a normal fashion.
